subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On PALM
msgSnippet: ... Yes: eastern New England, parts of Scotland, Ireland, the Caribbean. ... As I ve been saying, essentially no dialect makes a solid distinction here. --
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> I assume you are lumping together NORTH/FORCE here because only a small
> group of speakers distinguishes between the two sets. (I do, but the
> distinction is pretty weak even for me.)

Yes: eastern New England, parts of Scotland, Ireland, the Caribbean.

> Anyway, I'm just trying to point out that the vowel before Roar
> situation needs to be discussed a bit more. I see words appearing in the
> news that still give me difficulty. Besides the example above, I come
> across the Ed Roar combination for words in which I would use Age-Roar.
> It takes me a while to figure out such words.

As I've been saying, essentially no dialect makes a solid distinction here.

--
John Cowan cowan@... ccil.org/~cowan
Dievas dave dantis; Dievas duos duonos --Lithuanian proverb
Deus dedit dentes; deus dabit panem --Latin version thereof
Deity donated dentition;
deity'll donate doughnuts --English version by Muke Tever
God gave gums; God'll give granary --Version by Mat McVeagh

> I assume you are lumping together NORTH/FORCE here because only a small 
> group of speakers distinguishes between the two sets. (I do, but the 
> distinction is pretty weak even for me.)

Yes: eastern New England, parts of Scotland, Ireland, the Caribbean.

> Anyway, I'm just trying to point out that the vowel before Roar 
> situation needs to be discussed a bit more. I see words appearing in the 
> news that still give me difficulty. Besides the example above, I come

As I've been saying, essentially no dialect makes a solid distinction here.
